newsitem.title: USA: Comcast debt tightens on Microsoft news.
newsitem.headline: Comcast debt tightens on Microsoft news.

text.p: Comcast Corp's outstanding debt tightened by 10 to 12 basis points on Monday morning in response to news that Microsoft Inc was making a $1 billion investment in the Philadelpia-based cable operator.

Comcast's 20-year bonds were quoted at 139-134 basis points over comparable Treasuries in Monday morning trading, a trader said. That spread was 12 basis points tighter than their opening level, he added.
The company's senior long-term debt is rated Ba1/BBB-minus.

Among high-yield bonds, the entire domestic cable sector was benefitting from the Comcast and Microsoft news, as well as reports that Cablevision Systems Corp is close to acquiring a large number of New York subscribers from Tele-Communications Inc, traders said.
Junk bonds from U.S. cable operators were approximately one point tighter in morning trading, one trader said.
Corporate bond analysts said the Microsoft investment in Comcast had positive implications for the entire cable industry.
"This is an affirmation of cable television technology as a platform for providing on-line, two-way services," said G. Robert Berzins, high-yield bond cable analyst at Lehman Brothers Inc.
He noted the large equity investment was an obvious plus for Comcast as well.
"It's never bad when you can get the richest guy in the country to invest in your company," said another analyst, referring to Bill Gates, a major shareholder of Microsoft.
